title: Why Vendors and Partners Are Both Essential in Business
description: Organizations should think about both as players on their team.
author: Louise K. Allen
excerpt: “Partner” and “vendor” aren’t really at odds. Here's how to better understand that they are both valuable relationships in business.
text: In business-to-business tech, the rhetoric of being a partner rather than a vendor has become so common it’s almost lost its meaning. Still, the implication — that a partner is an inherently superior thing to be — remains obvious. By branding themselves as partners, B2B tech businesses communicate their commitment to a long-lasting relationship, collaborative problem-solving, and ongoing growth.That can be an incredibly powerful proposition for leaders. They are excited to work in concert with their workflow platform provider or cybersecurity experts, for example, to drive innovation and progress. But what if that’s not the goal? Then, partner and vendor aren’t at odds, nor is one inherently more valuable than the other. The better option depends on the parties involved, the services being provided, and the goals of the customer.Vendor versus partner: Not better, but differentSome business professionals are quick to say a partner’s collaborative commitment beats out a vendor’s every time. But consider this decision outside of the workplace. Imagine you’re a soccer player training for a tournament. There are plenty of people who contribute their expertise as you prepare for the big day. However, not all of them are partners, nor should they be.Of course, you want your relationship with your coach to feel like a mutually beneficial alliance. Ideally, that person, throughout time, learns about your goals and develops strategies to help you succeed. The coach may oversee workout plans, make recommendations, and implement training strategies to help you perform at the highest level. Do you bring your coach to the store to buy new cleats? Unlikely. As you wander down the aisle, browsing the size, style, and color options, you don’t call your coach. You ask a retail associate, aka a vendor, who is trained to understand the inventory and help you make the best decision.Whether helping a customer nail down their size or asking questions about lifestyle, the associate is there to help ensure you leave the store with exactly what you need. While there’s no denying that the coach plays a much bigger role in the athlete’s life than the sales associate, that doesn’t diminish the value of getting the right advice from an expert in their field. In fact, utilizing both the coach and the store employee maximizes the athlete’s benefits — it’s just a matter of understanding their separate roles.What do you really want?Picking between a vendor and a partner doesn’t need to be a game that one team wins and one team loses. Instead, organizations should think about both options as players on their team. There’s value in both types of relationships when the time is right. Partners are intended to help organizations pursue big, strategic goals that require ongoing engagement, external expertise, deep organizational understanding, and incremental change. Vendors are there to support smaller, more contained initiatives. They can also help to augment teams that already have the necessary expertise in-house but who need the right product or solution to support the effort.Yes, partner does sound better. That’s someone who cares about you, works with you, and is interested in more than a transaction. A vendor? The stigma is that they’re just there for your money, but that’s not true. The fact is, sometimes, you’re looking for a long-term, strategic relationship that can help you grow and exceed your goals. html:
In business-to-business tech, the rhetoric of being a partner rather than a vendor has become so common it’s almost lost its meaning. Still, the implication — that a partner is an inherently superior thing to be — remains obvious. By branding themselves as partners, B2B tech businesses communicate their commitment to a long-lasting relationship, collaborative problem-solving, and ongoing growth.

That can be an incredibly powerful proposition for leaders. They are excited to work in concert with their workflow platform provider or cybersecurity experts, for example, to drive innovation and progress. But what if that’s not the goal? Then, partner and vendor aren’t at odds, nor is one inherently more valuable than the other. The better option depends on the parties involved, the services being provided, and the goals of the customer.

Vendor versus partner: Not better, but different

Some business professionals are quick to say a partner’s collaborative commitment beats out a vendor’s every time. But consider this decision outside of the workplace. Imagine you’re a soccer player training for a tournament. There are plenty of people who contribute their expertise as you prepare for the big day. However, not all of them are partners, nor should they be.

Of course, you want your relationship with your coach to feel like a mutually beneficial alliance. Ideally, that person, throughout time, learns about your goals and develops strategies to help you succeed. The coach may oversee workout plans, make recommendations, and implement training strategies to help you perform at the highest level. 

Do you bring your coach to the store to buy new cleats? Unlikely. As you wander down the aisle, browsing the size, style, and color options, you don’t call your coach. You ask a retail associate, aka a vendor, who is trained to understand the inventory and help you make the best decision.

Whether helping a customer nail down their size or asking questions about lifestyle, the associate is there to help ensure you leave the store with exactly what you need. While there’s no denying that the coach plays a much bigger role in the athlete’s life than the sales associate, that doesn’t diminish the value of getting the right advice from an expert in their field. In fact, utilizing both the coach and the store employee maximizes the athlete’s benefits — it’s just a matter of understanding their separate roles.

What do you really want?

Picking between a vendor and a partner doesn’t need to be a game that one team wins and one team loses. Instead, organizations should think about both options as players on their team. There’s value in both types of relationships when the time is right. 

Partners are intended to help organizations pursue big, strategic goals that require ongoing engagement, external expertise, deep organizational understanding, and incremental change. Vendors are there to support smaller, more contained initiatives. They can also help to augment teams that already have the necessary expertise in-house but who need the right product or solution to support the effort.

Yes, partner does sound better. That’s someone who cares about you, works with you, and is interested in more than a transaction. A vendor? The stigma is that they’re just there for your money, but that’s not true. The fact is, sometimes, you’re looking for a long-term, strategic relationship that can help you grow and exceed your goals. In other situations, you may just be looking for a new pair of cleats — and there’s nothing wrong with that.
